prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus east
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is for the survey toward 11 sources in the east part of perseus molecular cloud complex.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are going to observe CCH and CH3OH as representatives of carbon-chain molecules and COMs, respectively. At the same time, other carbon-chain molecules and COMs, can be observed simultaneously. They are useful for detailed characterization of the chemical composition of each source, and hence, we would like to observe them as much as possible for supplementary information in conducting this program. CH3CHO, HCOOH, NH2CHO, and HCOOCH3 are expected to be detected for the hot-corino like sources. In fact, the lines of these molecules having similar upper-state energies and line strengths (Smu2) are detected in the previous observation toward IRAS 16293-2422 (ALMA Cycle 0) and NGC 1333 IRAS4A (PdBI). Since our proposed sensitivity is higher than or similar to these previous observations, we have a good chance to detect these lines in some sources. On the other hand, the intensity of the c-C3H2 lines are typically 2/3 of that of CCH, and hence, the c-C3H2 lines will be detected in WCCC like sources. With observations of these supplementary lines, we can discuss the chemical characteristics more in detail. The SO line is necessary for investigating existence of the centrifugal barrier (See section 4(4) in the text). The SiO line is a good tracer of the outflow, which is useful to discriminate the outflow contribution from the disk/envelope component. H13CN and CS exist both in the outflow and the disk/envelope component, which can be used as 'standard' molecules to trace the total amount of the gas associated to each protostar.

We would like to delineate the 100 AU scale chemical composition in order to confirm the chemical diversity of the protostellar envelope and to duscuss the chemical evolution toward protoplanetary disks. The Perseus molecular cloud complex is located at a distance of 250 pc from the Sun, and hence, we need to observe the sources at an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds.

The linewidths of CCH, c-C3H2, CH3OH(narrow component), and CH3CHO observed with the single-dish telescopes tipycally range from 0.5 to 4 km/s in velocity. Thus, we require the velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. As for the bright lines such as CS and SO, we will discuss where the species exist inside the dense core (i.e. in the infalling envelope, centrifugal barrier, or the disk) at a higher velocity resolution (0.17 km/s). Thus we request the velocity resolution of 0.17 km/s (141.133 kHz).
The peak flux density of the CCH lines observed in L1527 (D=137 pc) is 0.195 Jy/0.7"beam. The sources in Perseus molecular cloud complex are located in 250 pc. Hence, the peak flux density will be 0.195 Jy/0.4"beam in the distance of 250 pc. We would like to map the lines with the S/N ratio of higher than 3 sigma for the sources whose CCH line intensity is 10 times weaker than the above prediction (i.e. we will make a statistics with the dynamic range of >10.). Thus, we need the rms noise of 6.5 mJy/0.4"beam (0.195/10/3=0.0065). The line intensities of CH$_3$OH in hot corino sources are similar to or stronger than that of CCH in L1527. Thus, the above estimate is also feasible for the CH3OH lines. As a result, we can discuss the CH3OH/CCH ratios with the dynamic range of >100. The peak fulx density of the CS and SO lines are stronger than that of CCH, and hense, the above rms noise is enough.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus northwest
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is for the survey toward 17 sources in the north-west oart of the perseus molecular cloud complex(NGC133).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are going to observe CCH and CH3OH as representatives of carbon-chain molecules and COMs, respectively. At the same time, other carbon-chain molecules and COMs, can be observed simultaneously. They are useful for detailed characterization of the chemical composition of each source, and hence, we would like to observe them as much as possible for supplementary information in conducting this program. The Perseus molecular cloud complex is located at a distance of 250 pc from the Sun, and hence, we need to observe the sources at an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds.

The linewidths of CCH, c-C3H2, CH3OH(narrow component), and CH3CHO observed with the single-dish telescopes tipycally range from 0.5 to 4 km/s in velocity. As for the bright lines such as CS and SO, we will discuss where the species exist inside the dense core (i.e. in the infalling envelope, centrifugal barrier, or the disk) at a higher velocity resolution (0.17 km/s). The peak flux density of the CCH lines observed in L1527 (D=137 pc) is 0.195 Jy/0.7"beam. The sources in Perseus molecular cloud complex are located in 250 pc. Thus, the above estimate is also feasible for the CH3OH lines. As a result, we can discuss the CH3OH/CCH ratios with the dynamic range of >100. The peak fulx density of the CS and SO lines are stronger than that of CCH, and hense, the above rms noise is enough.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus southwest
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is for the survey toward 9 sources in the south-west part of the perseus molecular cloud complex.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are going to observe CCH and CH3OH as representatives of carbon-chain molecules and COMs, respectively. At the same time, other carbon-chain molecules and COMs, can be observed simultaneously. They are useful for detailed characterization of the chemical composition of each source, and hence, we would like to observe them as much as possible for supplementary information in conducting this program. Thus, the above estimate is also feasible for the CH3OH lines. As a result, we can discuss the CH3OH/CCH ratios with the dynamic range of >100. The peak fulx density of the CS and SO lines are stronger than that of CCH, and hense, the above rms noise is enough.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is well known that low-mass protostellar cores show significant chemical diversity. One distinct case is hot corino chemistry characterized by rich saturated complex organic molecules, while the other distinct case is warm carbon chain chemistry (WCCC) characterized by rich carbon-chain molecules. However, the number of sources definitively classified into them are limited, and the statistics is apparently poor. We here propose to conduct an unbiased survey of chemical composition toward 37 Class 0/I protostars in the Perseus molecular cloud complex. Our recent observations toward these target sources with the single-dish telescopes shows clear chemical diversity, where many intermediate sources are found between the two distinct cases. We are going to confirm this result with ALMA to establish chemical diversity in the 200 AU scale. A relative occurrence of each category (hot corino chemistry, WCCC, or intermediate) as well as preferential association of the sources in each category with a specific part of the cloud complex will give us an important clue to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity in terms of evolutionary history and/or environmental effects.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Science, The University of Tokyo
